steamdeck-u.name: SteamDeck U
steamdeck-u.description: This project is a custom theme for Valve's Steam Deck. It uses a homebrew plugin for injecting CSS to provide users with options to customize each part of their keyboard. The reason I started this project is because Valve offers keyboard themes, but the selection is limited and they only work online.

data.text: This project is a custom theme for Valve's Steam Deck. It uses a homebrew plugin for injecting CSS to provide users with options to customize each part of their keyboard. The reason I started this project is because Valve offers keyboard themes, but the selection is limited and they only work online.

items.content: Wanted to contribute to the homebrew Steam Deck community
Wanted a more customizable alternative to the existing keyboards
Wanted customizable keyboards that worked offline
Came up with a unique idea for the homebrew community
Created a highly customizable keyboard that also works offline

marching-squares.name: Marching Squares
marching-squares.description: The goal of this project was to recreate the Marching Squares algorithm in blender. Marching Squares is a well known computer graphics algorithm used to generate procedural patterns for a multitude of uses, such as terrain in game design.

data.text: The goal of this project was to recreate the Marching Squares algorithm in blender. Marching Squares is a well known computer graphics algorithm used to generate procedural patterns for a multitude of uses, such as terrain in game design.

While it may not be very complicated to create marching squares through programming, Blender's Geometry Nodes are another story entirely. Because of how geometry nodes work, there is no looping or re-using data in the typical programming sense. Data is, in most cases, computed based on where it is called from (more info can be found about that here). This made recreating marching squares significantly more complicated. The image below is what the logic for this project looks like (normally I use node groups to make working on it possible, this is what it looks like without them):

items.content: Wanted to create a geometry nodes implementation of marching squares
Gained a better understanding of how to solve problems with geometry nodes
Have a better understanding of how geometry nodes work internally

portfolio-updater.name: Portfolio Updater
portfolio-updater.description: Initially, this project was going to be written using the Electron framework, but right around when I started it, I heard about Tauri. Tauri is great because it allows you to build more secure apps with smaller bundle sizes, and has a better developer experience then Electron. The app itself makes updating my portfolio easy and straightforward, allowing me to focus more on my projects.

data.text: Initially, this project was going to be written using the Electron framework, but right around when I started it, I heard about Tauri. Tauri is great because it allows you to build more secure apps with smaller bundle sizes, and has a better developer experience then Electron. The app itself makes updating my portfolio easy and straightforward, allowing me to focus more on my projects.

Added buttons for archive management

Fixed issue with project's org prop not being updated when added to an Organization's projects list

Got to learn the basics of the Tauri framework

tweakpane-gradient-plugin.name: Tweakpane Gradient Plugin
tweakpane-gradient-plugin.description: I started this project because I had been using the Tweakpane library for editable parameters in another project, and needed a gradient texture input. The layout and controls are based on Blender's color ramp node, which node, which does something similar. The plugin allows the user to edit the stop position and color for the gradient, and then outputs an ImageData object with the consequent texture.

data.text: I started this project because I had been using the Tweakpane library for editable parameters in another project, and needed a gradient texture input. The layout and controls are based on Blender's color ramp node, which node, which does something similar. The plugin allows the user to edit the stop position and color for the gradient, and then outputs an ImageData object with the consequent texture.

items.content: Needed a Tweakpane compatible gradient generator
Created a plugin that allows the user to customize gradient textures
First introduction to the MVC design pattern

three.js-marching-cubes.name: Three.js Marching Cubes
three.js-marching-cubes.description: The Marching Cubes is a well known algorithm often used in games for terrain generation. The premise is it generates polygons based on weights applied to each vertex of the bounding cube. I have always found this algorithm interesting, so I decided to recreate it using TypeScript and one of my favorite libraries, Three.js.

data.text: The Marching Cubes is a well known algorithm often used in games for terrain generation. The premise is it generates polygons based on weights applied to each vertex of the bounding cube. I have always found this algorithm interesting, so I decided to recreate it using TypeScript and one of my favorite libraries, Three.js.

items.content: I wanted to recreate the Marching Cubes algorithm using Three.js and Typescript
I wanted to refamiliarize myself with Three.js
I learned useful strategies for optimizing Three.js applications
I was able to recreate the algorithm
I was able to refresh my memory on Three.js

noisy-dots.name: Noisy Dots
noisy-dots.description: This small project is a simple animation made using the HTML5 canvas and simplex-noise. I came up with this idea because I wanted to add something to my portfolio landing page to make it more unique, and I love procedural generation so I thought a noise based animation would be perfect! It works by sampling a noise texture and scaling circles based on the value (noise ranges from 0.0 - 1.0), which creates the mesmerizing pattern.

data.text: This small project is a simple animation made using the HTML5 canvas and simplex-noise. I came up with this idea because I wanted to add something to my portfolio landing page to make it more unique, and I love procedural generation so I thought a noise based animation would be perfect! It works by sampling a noise texture and scaling circles based on the value (noise ranges from 0.0 - 1.0), which creates the mesmerizing pattern.

items.content: I wanted to add something unique to my portfolio landing page
Was interested in exploring the use of procedural noise in web design
Created something unique that helps my portfolio make an impact on viewers

data.text: This component of the website is a quick overview of the organization and our main tools.
The FAQ component covers the questions we get asked on a regularly.
The last component is the wiki. This will serve as a replacement for our GitHub wiki once we get everything migrated over.

vite-plugin-sitemap.name: Vite-Plugin-Sitemap
vite-plugin-sitemap.description: I had the idea to make this little npm package because I was working on my portfolio, and came across a neat rollup plugin for generating sitemaps. Vite allows users to use most rollup plugins, so I just used that, but it caused some issues, so I decided to write my own with some added features.

hex-world-generator.name: Hex World Generator
hex-world-generator.description: I started this project after coming across a video about how to make the base of the project (the hex shaped grid). Thought it looked interesting so I made it, and added decorations to the different areas.

data.text: I started this project after coming across a video about how to make the base of the project (the hex shaped grid). Thought it looked interesting so I made it, and added decorations to the different areas.

The way this project works is through using on of Blender's newer features, Geometry Nodes. These allow you to create 3D models almost 'programmatically'. They can be grouped together to create controller nodes as well, which is what I did for this project. This means someone could edit specific parameters to their liking without having to slog through hundreds of nodes.

items.content: Wanted to learn more about how Geometry Nodes worked
Wanted to create a procedural mini world and model some low poly models
Gained a better understanding of how Blender's Geometry Nodes work
Created a procedurally generated world with low poly decorations

simple-sudoku.name: Simple Sudoku
simple-sudoku.description: I came across an article about different ways to approach generating sudoku puzzles and solving them, and it caught my interest. I thought it would be a fun way to work on my web development skills and create a fun end product I could actually put up online. It was very interesting to explore how to not just generate solvable puzzles, but puzzles that look good to the player.

torc-character-designer.name: TORC Character Designer
torc-character-designer.description: This is one of my favorite projects. It is an external character creator and outfit designer for Star Wars The Old Republic. I really love this game and the community, and wanted to do something everyone could use and enjoy. It is very complexed, and I had to learn a lot of new topics and skills while working on it. I'm also very proud of it since it is the first tool of its kind made by anyone, ever, and that required me to solve a lot of problems no one else has done  before.

data.text: This is one of my favorite projects. It is an external character creator and outfit designer for Star Wars The Old Republic. I really love this game and the community, and wanted to do something everyone could use and enjoy. It is very complexed, and I had to learn a lot of new topics and skills while working on it. I'm also very proud of it since it is the first tool of its kind made by anyone, ever, and that required me to solve a lot of problems no one else has done  before.

items.content: I wanted to make something truly unique that had not been done before.
This is the only Star Wars The Old Republic external character designer
I also wanted to make something people would not only want to use, but also something that would inspire people, and help them realize what they can do.
I had read comments and posts on a variety of platforms from people requesting/asking about a character viewer/creator, the earliest dating back to around 2014.
I also wanted to expedite the process from re-creating your character outside of the game (for 3D modeling, printing, or just for fun).
The process could take upwards of one to two hour for one character.
With my program, it takes ~20 minutes.

decky-frontend-lib.name: Decky Frontend Lib
decky-frontend-lib.description: The Decky Frontend Lib is a library with reversed engineered UI components, custom components and utility classes. The library helps plugin developers integrate their plugins seamlessly with Valve's react UI, and modify css styles without affecting the regular UI.

portfolio-v2.description: This project is the website you are currently on. It is a replacement for my previous portfolio website, which I had not been keeping up to date. I decided to remake it from scratch using Svelte, TypeScript, and SASS (later removed), all of which are awesome frameworks I have wanted to learn for a while.

slicers-gui.name: Slicers GUI
slicers-gui.description: This is by far the project I am the most proud of. It is the culmination of a lot of work by both me and the SWTOR Slicers community, and the result is a truly unique piece of software that serves its purpose well. The idea behind making it was to optimize and improve all existing tools, and bundle them all into one cohesive, fully customizable application.

bash-shortcuts.name: Bash Shortcuts
bash-shortcuts.description: Bash Shortcuts is a homebrew plugin for valve's Steam Deck. The main purpose is to make running applications outside of steam games easier by providing a simple way to make your own shortcuts. These are run using Bash and a hidden Steam shortcut.

data.text: Bash Shortcuts is a homebrew plugin for valve's Steam Deck. The main purpose is to make running applications outside of steam games easier by providing a simple way to make your own shortcuts. These are run using Bash and a hidden Steam shortcut.

Part of my motivation for purchasing a Steam Deck was that I knew there would be a community development scene around it, so I was happy to contribute to that. It was also a great learning experience as well. I had to use SSH to access my Steam Deck in order to deploy and test the plugin, as well as learn the basics of React.
The main plugin view allows the user to run their shortcuts as well as manage and manually reload them.
The add menu allows the user to add their own shortcuts by providing a name and a bash command.

The manage view allows users to edit existing shortcuts as well as reorder them. This order will be reflected both here as well as in the main view, allowing users to put their most used shortcuts towards the top.
Once the user runs a shortcut, it will be launched full screen. When they decide they are done they can either quit using Steam's menu, or using the custom 'Close Shortcut' button in the plugin.

items.content: Wanted to contribute to the Steam Deck homebrew community
Wanted an easier way to launch applications from SteamOS
Learned how to use SSH
Familiarized myself with the basics of React

torc-npc-3d-viewers.name: TORC NPC 3D Viewers
torc-npc-3d-viewers.description: This project came about as a natural continuation of the TORCommunity Character Designer. It is a 3D viewer for loading the models for different NPC (non player characters) from Star Wars: The Old Republic. It uses a very similar process to the character designer for loading the models, but this time has to take a dynamic input specified on page load.

data.text: This project came about as a natural continuation of the TORCommunity Character Designer. It is a 3D viewer for loading the models for different NPC (non player characters) from Star Wars: The Old Republic. It uses a very similar process to the character designer for loading the models, but this time has to take a dynamic input specified on page load.

items.content: Natural continuation of my previous project, the Character Designer
Was a request feature for the TORCommunity website
One of the other fan sites, JediPedia, had a similar feature that was never flushed out
Wanted to refine my methods for loading and rendering models
I know how to load models more efficiently
The rendering process I use in a variety of projects is more refined
I was able to design a product that had been requested by people for a few years in a short amount of time

wiki-editor.name: Wiki Editor
wiki-editor.description: I had the idea for this project after I started working on a website for the SWTOR Slicers. We wanted to transition from using GitHub's wiki system to using our own on the new website, and so I had the idea to make an app for creating, editing, and deleting wiki articles. The app uses similar principles to my Portfolio Updater app, but is written using the Electron framework.

data.text: I had the idea for this project after I started working on a website for the SWTOR Slicers. We wanted to transition from using GitHub's wiki system to using our own on the new website, and so I had the idea to make an app for creating, editing, and deleting wiki articles. The app uses similar principles to my Portfolio Updater app, but is written using the Electron framework.

items.content: Needed a way to efficiently manage wiki articles for the SWTOR Slicers website.
Wanted to continue learning about the Svelte library
Was able to create an intuitive app for managing the SWTOR Slicers Wiki
Got to experiment with more advanced svelte components

tor-model-locator.name: Tor Model Locator
tor-model-locator.description: This is a little NPM package that assists the Slicers GUI in locating SWTOR model files from an extraction. Under the hood it is relatively simple, consisting of parsing a JSON file, gathering the needed files, and copying them into a predictable folder structure. This program has gone through 3 different major versions. As a proof of concept I wrote it in python (really easy to iterate with, but not reliable enough for me to choose for production), then I wrote it in GO as an executable bundled with the Slicers GUI. There were no issues with that version, however I would like to migrate the Slicers GUI to an all TS/Rust Tauri app, so I rewrote the program again as an NPM package.

data.text: This is a little NPM package that assists the Slicers GUI in locating SWTOR model files from an extraction. Under the hood it is relatively simple, consisting of parsing a JSON file, gathering the needed files, and copying them into a predictable folder structure. This program has gone through 3 different major versions. As a proof of concept I wrote it in python (really easy to iterate with, but not reliable enough for me to choose for production), then I wrote it in GO as an executable bundled with the Slicers GUI. There were no issues with that version, however I would like to migrate the Slicers GUI to an all TS/Rust Tauri app, so I rewrote the program again as an NPM package.

items.content: Wanted to keep the program modular (as it can be used on its own)
Wanted to transition to an all TS solution
Learned a bit about writing a good ReadMe file

swtor-slicers-wiki.name: SWTOR Slicers Wiki
swtor-slicers-wiki.description: The SWTOR Slicers Wiki is a collection of guides that serve to help people through the various processes involved in data mining, extraction, and modding. It continues to grow as we add more and more tutorials, and serves as a one stop shop for all things SWTOR Slicers.

data.text: The SWTOR Slicers Wiki is a collection of guides that serve to help people through the various processes involved in data mining, extraction, and modding. It continues to grow as we add more and more tutorials, and serves as a one stop shop for all things SWTOR Slicers.

items.content: We wanted to have a better way to explain the ins and outs of our community (we previously just had pdfs)
I wanted to organize our guides into a more intuitive design, and provide a place to put documentation of our work.

tetris.name: Tetris
tetris.description: For my last classic game project, I wanted to do something much more complexed. I decided to do Tetris, as it is one of my favorite games, and had a lot of complexed elements. It took much longer then the previous three projects, but was very satisfying to finish.

data.text: For my last classic game project, I wanted to do something much more complexed. I decided to do Tetris, as it is one of my favorite games, and had a lot of complexed elements. It took much longer then the previous three projects, but was very satisfying to finish.

items.content: Wanted to finish of my web game projects with something that was more complicated
Wanted to practice and advance my javascript knowledge
Tetris has guidelines you need to follow if you are going to publish it under the Tetris name, and I thought it would be good practice to make a project with specifications I also needed to meet
Learned how to better mitigate methods and functions to the most relevant class object
I became comfortable and very familiar with javascript
I met most the required guidelines. (Some were too advanced for me at the time, but I plan to come back and update it to meet them)

minesweeper.name: Minesweeper
minesweeper.description: Minesweeper is a classic logic based strategy game. As I was learning JavaScript, I thought it would be fun to make one of my favorite classic games using what I was learning. In the process, I learned about the html5 canvas, which is now used instead of flash for web based games and animations. After completing the normal minesweeper, I wanted to add something more advanced to the project. I decided to add animations (inspired by Google' Minesweeper), so I used the html5 canvas API to animate it.

data.text: Minesweeper is a classic logic based strategy game. As I was learning JavaScript, I thought it would be fun to make one of my favorite classic games using what I was learning. In the process, I learned about the html5 canvas, which is now used instead of flash for web based games and animations. After completing the normal minesweeper, I wanted to add something more advanced to the project. I decided to add animations (inspired by Google' Minesweeper), so I used the html5 canvas API to animate it.

items.content: Wanted to learn how to use the HTML5 canvas
Love Minesweeper, so wanted to make my own version
Wanted to learn more javascript and do some more web development
I was comfortable and familiar with html, css, javascript, and the Canvas API
How to approach a problem from different angles (realized that I would need to use the html5 canvas api if I wanted to make animations)
Learned about recursion

pong.name: Pong
pong.description: Keeping with the theme of the previous projects I had just finished, I decided to make a 2 player pong game. This was much more complexed then minesweeper as I needed to update the canvas on key press, as well as slowly increase the ball speed and have collision detection.

data.text: Keeping with the theme of the previous projects I had just finished, I decided to make a 2 player pong game. This was much more complexed then minesweeper as I needed to update the canvas on key press, as well as slowly increase the ball speed and have collision detection.

intro-to-web-dev-camp.name: Intro to web dev camp
intro-to-web-dev-camp.description: This project was a venture into an area I had absolutely no experience with, teaching. I had the idea to make the camp because my school gave me the opportunity to get into computer science, and I wanted to offer others that opportunity as well. I also saw the camp as a great way to solidify my understanding of web development.

discord-modbot.name: Discord Modbot
discord-modbot.description: Modbot was a project I started after I had finished learning Java and was familiar with JavaScript and SpringBoot. This allowed me to make a more advanced project, as I already knew the foundations. For this project, I decided to split the Database from the Discord Bot. This meant that I needed to learn how to send Java to Java JSON data. I also made a frontend for users to interact with, which was my second web development project.

The Front End UI (Allows users to tailor the bot to their specific needs)

the-memedb.name: The MemeDB
the-memedb.description: The memeDB was one of my first projects. I had finished AP Java a few months earlier, so I was still relatively new to programming. I read about SpringBoot (an API framework for Java), and immediately wanted to make my own. I decided that a fun and interesting idea would be to make a meme database, so I went with that. First I made an API with SpringBoot, and then a React.js front end. I later realized that React was not suited for my needs, as I wanted to make a multipage website, so I switched to normal JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. This was my first attempt at web development, and I enjoyed it a lot.

data.text: The memeDB was one of my first projects. I had finished AP Java a few months earlier, so I was still relatively new to programming. I read about SpringBoot (an API framework for Java), and immediately wanted to make my own. I decided that a fun and interesting idea would be to make a meme database, so I went with that. First I made an API with SpringBoot, and then a React.js front end. I later realized that React was not suited for my needs, as I wanted to make a multipage website, so I switched to normal JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. This was my first attempt at web development, and I enjoyed it a lot.

items.content: Wanted to try something new
Had just learned about SpringBoot, and wanted to learn the basics
Wanted to learn web development
Learned the basics of SpringBoot
Learned SQL
Finished my first web UI
The UI. It was a very simple UI as I was still learning, but I was satisfied with it.
The API (Application Programming Interface). This was the server hosting the database and API the UI communicated with and pulled from.

slicers-blender-importer.name: Slicers Blender Importer
slicers-blender-importer.description: The blender importer was very different before I started making changes. I added multi file importing, as well as one click imports. The one click imports work with the TORC Character Designer and my Locator tool to import all models and materials for a given SWTOR character, allowing artists to get right to making art.

data.text: The blender importer was very different before I started making changes. I added multi file importing, as well as one click imports. The one click imports work with the TORC Character Designer and my Locator tool to import all models and materials for a given SWTOR character, allowing artists to get right to making art.

items.content: Added support for all SWTOR NPC types
Wanted to help contribute to the organization
People had been asking for multi model importing for a while
I wanted to automate the last piece of the process, as I had already done the first two
Was able to meet people's requests for multi file importing
I was able to fully automate the importing process, taking a nearly 2 hour process and making it take 20 seconds

swtor-slicers.name: SWTOR Slicers
swtor-slicers.about: The SWTOR Slicers Collaboration is a group who enjoys taking Star Wars The Old Republic beyond the game. Whether this be through using models for fan films, or creating tools for the community (such as my Character and Outfit Designer), the community enjoys finding new and unique was to utilize the game.
swtor-slicers.description: I got involved with the community because of my work on the Character and Outfit Designer. This was because I added a secondary feature to my tool, the ability to download a .zip file with all of the nessesary information to recreate the character in Blender. This in tandem with other tools I have made expedites the extraction process. Since finishing the Character Designer, I continue to help people, as well as work to make the process even easier.

torcommunity.name: TORCommunity.com
torcommunity.about: TORCommunity.com is a fan site for Star Wars The Old Republic. It was started in 2008, and has many neat features, such as guides, walkthroughs, tips, tools, and multiple databases. The sites goal is to provide great resources, and improve the experience players have while playing the game.
torcommunity.description: I got involved with TORCommunity after the owner and head dev of the site reached out to me while I was working on the Character and Outfit Designer and asked if I would be willing to put it up on TORCommunity. He had been looking for a tool just like it for the site for a while, and I was hoping to get it up on one of the fan sites as well. After finishing the app, and putting it up live on the site, he offered me the opportunity to continue working on the site, which I gladly took him up on. Since then, I have continued to work on the Character and Outfit Designer, as well as other parts of the site.

steam-deck-homebrew.name: Steam Deck Homebrew
steam-deck-homebrew.about: Steam Deck Homebrew (SDH) is a group of programmers, designers and more whose goal is to bring awesome new functionality to the Steam Deck.
steam-deck-homebrew.description: My involvement with SDH started when I came across the Decky Plugin Loader. Since then I have published my own plugin and contributed to the reverse engineered UI components the organization uses

synergy-animal-behavior-behavior-assista.description: Created and managed client databases and resources for Synergy Animal Behavior as a summer job.

city-wood-external-developer.description: I worked on creating an inventory management tool (dubbed Log Tracker) for City Wood. The web app uses Firebase for hosting, authentication, and data storage, as well as Google Cloud for the Gmail and Maps APIs. I completed the beta stage and stopped receiving contact, so the project remains unfinished.

let-the-wookie-win.name: Let the Wookie Win
let-the-wookie-win.description: If you are a Star Wars fan you may recognize the name of this piece. It was inspired by a scene from Star Wars IV: A New Hope.

swtor-neon-sign.name: SWTOR Neon Sign
swtor-neon-sign.description: This piece is a 3D render of a neon sign inspired SWTOR (Star Wars The Old Republic) logo, made in blender. This was my first original piece.

operative-neon-sign.name: Operative Neon Sign
operative-neon-sign.description: This was my second attempt to make a neon sign using blender. It has a bit more detail then the previous one, and the pipes and corners are a bit cleaner.

guardian-neon-sign.name: Guardian Neon Sign
guardian-neon-sign.description: This piece was my third and most recent attemp at making a neon sign in blender. I was satisfied with how the previous sign turned out, however I wanted to add more detail. I settled on modeling a bracket, screws, and clips to 'hold' the sign to the brick wall behind, which turned out really nice.

vault-hunter-neon.name: Vault Hunter Neon
vault-hunter-neon.description: This piece is based on the vault hunter's icon from borderlands 2. I tried making a more realistic brick wall, but the realism took away from the sign itself, so I reverted it back to the older material.

apex-legends-sign.name: Apex Legends Sign
apex-legends-sign.description: When I started on this piece I had been having a blast playing Apex Legends, so it was a no-brainer. I decided to try some new techniques, such as the wooden background.

cyberpunk-city-(ai).name: Cyberpunk City (AI)
cyberpunk-city-(ai).description: AI art has been a hot topic as of late. I decided to try them out and see how easy it was to tell that an AI made the art (this piece is the best result I got). Pieces from the same AI have clear similarities, which is amusing as it shows that it's just an algorithm.

alloy-oil-effect.name: Alloy Oil Effect
alloy-oil-effect.description: This piece is a stylized version of one of the concept art images for Horizon Zero Dawn. I made this as I was learning how to modify images with Gimp. As the name implies, the goal was to create an oil painting effect.
